Interview Questions: Name some things you liked about a previous supervisor and why. Name some things you disliked.

title: Senior Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Dec 2014
Interview Descriptions: Standard, nothing surprising.  Met with all managers and staff members. After the interview, they sent an offer letter in 3 weeks.  We negotiated moving expenses.  Tried to increase the salary but they refused to budge. Apparently the system wouldn't allow me to hire in above the salary of the former employee (who had less experience and knowledge) in this 'technical position'.  It is different for faculty positions.
Interview Questions: Are you ok with a technical position?

title: Statistical Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions: I had a phone interview going over the basic information and my general qualifications. I then was asked to meet with the team each of which asked me questions regarding my work history, my expectations for the position, as well as, their expectations.
Interview Questions: What statistical data analysis programs are you familiar with and how long have you used them professionally. Give examples of times you used each for projects and the tests you ran in them.

title: Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Nov 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was not rigorous. The most important aspect to landing a job is solid classroom performance as a student. Also, it is necessary to reach out to the professor teaching the course/section. They ultimately decide who to take as undergraduate teaching assistants and can make or break the decision based off of personal preference. It's a rather biased system, if you ask nicely and kiss up, you get in.
Interview Questions: What is your time commitment for the semester?

title: Office Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: I was emailed the job posting, and I emailed back my cover letter and resume. About two weeks later, I was asked to come in for a one-on-one interview. A few days after the interview, I was extended an offer.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview process was pretty standard. A phone interview, followed by a test on various microsoft programs, then an in person interview with 2 directors. The phone interview lasted about 15 minutes, while the in person interview lasted about 30 minutes. The test is what took the longest; about an hour and on a separate day then the on campus interview.
Interview Questions: Why did I want to work for Wash U? What could I bring to the team that someone else might not?

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: Emails communications first (a few) to know the short-term and long-term goals for your career. Understanding the differences from the research work before and what they need you to do, got to bring something on the table to convince them you have a motivation and skill set to accomplish new things. Skype calls discuss projects and coding technical questions. Webex conference to present for the entire group and questioned.
Interview Questions: technical details, coding abilities, relative algorithms; career developments, etc.

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Oct 2014
Interview Descriptions: It was interactive and casual. I had a phone interview first. They wanted to skype but my skype was not working. Than I suggested I can as well meet in person. We chatted about work I did followed by current lab projects. I interacted with other lab members,
Interview Questions: Accomplishments I made in the past. And how easily I would be able to learn new skills if required.

title: Executive Secretary Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: The process was fairly simple - some expected questions with a few behavioral-based questions thrown in ...  I interviewed for about 90 minutes on a Monday morning and was offered the position the next day.
Interview Questions: None were really unexpected.  Tell me about yourself; Tell me about a time when you disagreed with a co-worker, how did you handle it, and what was the outcome?  Tell me about a situation that you saved your department money - walk me through the specifics including $'s saved.  How did you recognize this was costing the department money?  I had read there would be behavioral-based questions so I was prepared.

title: PhD Candidate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed with 5 faculty members. Each interview was 30 minutes long. The faculty member spoke for about 15 minutes about his/her research. The rest of the time they wanted to hear about my previous research experience. Find out who you will be interviewing with and read their latest papers and ask questions about their research. They want to know that you can think like a scientist.
Interview Questions: If you had to come up with a project in my lab, given what you know about what we do, what would it be and why.

title: MSW Medical Case Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Aug 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview process began with a phone screening which lead to an in person interview at one of the medical school's facilities. I walked in and was met by rude rwcptionist who asked if I was a clientwaiting for my case manager (I was very nicely dressed and had obviously never been there before and have a very distinct accent) instead of simply asking how may they help me. I was then instructed to use a phone on the wall to call the person interviewing me. After about 15 min I was taken back and up a set of stairs only to be told I was entering a team panel interview and that she'd forgotten to tell me.
Interview Questions: How would you handle a doctor pushing you to have your client take medication.

title: Server Administrative Interview
Application Type: I applied through a recruiter. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jul 2014
Interview Descriptions:
Manager was 15 minutes late to a 30 minute interview. When I tried to chat with him on the walk to the meeting room he grunted at me. The entire interview was about 10 minutes long. He sat down and said nothing except to ask about 8 rapid fire tech questions. He wouldn't look at me or talk to me and kept looking at the time on his phone. 

Total waste of time.
Interview Questions: The 8 questions where pretty straight forward IT admin type questions.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: I got interview 20 days after application. It was a panel interview. They asked very straighforward questions and spent lot of time on describing job and how I am lacking experience in that particular research area.
Interview Questions: They did not ask any technical questions. It was a very basic interview

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: It takes about 30 minutes entirely to meet with directors of the division. They didn't ask any behavioral questions. All questions are related to my previous project experiences. They spent some time explaining their expectation about this position and what projects will this position work on.
Interview Questions: They asked me what I did in one of my project?

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1+ week. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jun 2014
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and then got an email asking about my interest in the lab. Next email was regarding scheduling the interview. It was Skype interview and there were two rounds. First interview was with the lab and recruitment coordinator and then after a few days with the main boss. First interview was short and was more like what I should expect in the final interview. Second interview was longer and we talked about a lot of things regarding my professional and personal interests. After interview I got an email offering me the job.
Interview Questions: Usual questions like tell about your previous research, why are you interested in WashU. Interview was relaxed and in both rounds I was made comfortable.

title: Associate Director Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: I met with an employee at the university who passed my resume along. The next day I received an email asking for a phone interview the following week. He asked me about my career trajectory and then spent 20 minutes explaining the position to me (this seemed odd). Then I asked about 5 questions, he told me I was articulate and seemed really smart and if the whole thing was based on our phone conversation, he would hire me. Then things got weird. He  spent about 40 minutes critiquing the formatting of my resume, telling me I needed more buzzwords and that there were too many jobs (it's 2 pages, there are 8, they are all entirely relevant). He told me I could resubmit my resume using his preferred formatting although it wouldn't make a difference in hiring. This was the most confusing interview I have ever been on– you cannot tailor a resume to every single person's whims, and if you have zero intention of hiring someone you don't a) schedule a formal interview with them, then b) complain that you're interviewing them, and then c) say if it was based on interviews alone, you would hire but as it stands someone else gave you buzzwords. Ultimately a bizarre, infuriating waste of time.
Interview Questions: He literally asked me zero questions after "Tell me about yourself." The rest was him talking at me.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions:
Received an email for onsite interview 20 days after I completed job application. Hiring manager was very friendly but the other panel member never seemed interested in interview and kept telling me over and over that I do not have relevant experience. I may be wrong but it felt like that whole interview was just a formality by the department to complete the requirement of interviewing X number of candidates. 

Two weeks later Hiring manager notified me that they have chosen someone else but she is forwarding my resume to other hiring managers for other CRC positions.
Interview Questions: Standard interview questions

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in May 2014
Interview Descriptions: Initially contacted PI by email also posted a CV on the DBBS website.  I received interest from 4 faculty members and was given two offers before accepting one of the offers and informing the other two faculty about my decision.  I went to visit and did two interviews on back to back days and received offers from both PIs.  The interviews were both full days spent talking with various members of the labs and the PIs followed by a seminar and more chats with other lab members.  At the end of the day I met with the PIs and received an offer on the spot from both of them.
Interview Questions: No difficult questions to speak of.

title: Librarian Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions:
Submitted my cover letter and resume, emailed to set up phone interview.  I was invited to the campus for an in person interview which was all day meeting multiple staff and/or peers.  I had a Power Point presentation of my own choosing which I presented in the morning, answered questions.  Lunch was casual with potential supervisor, dinner follow up with potential peers.  

The entire process was about a month.  I have had the interview but no communication so far 
(it has been 1 week).

The interview process was thoughtful and organized well.  It was a comfortable interview with a lot of open ended questions.  What are your hobbies?  How would you add value?  What is your working style?
Interview Questions: How do you resolve conflict in the work place?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: Apply for PHD program
Interview Questions: Future plan

title: Senior Associate Director of Development Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO)
Interview Descriptions:
Phase 1: Initial interview with prospective supervisor and perhaps their supervisor as well
Phase 2: 6 - 10 interviews, 30-minutes each, back to back over 1-2 days is the norm with peers or other managers you would not report to
Phase 3: Interview with Exec Vice Chancellor
Interview Questions: Lots of questions about specific gifts I had worked on in the past

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: I visited as a prospective PhD student for the Biomedical Engineering department. The experience was very standard for visiting PhD students. You're essentially already accepted into the program if you're given the offer to visit, and the BME department will offer an all expenses paid weekend visit to see their labs, facilities, and discuss research opportunities.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: 4 interviews, very friendly Professors, who are enthusiastic about their work.
Interview Questions: Some specific details about what I did in my research previously.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Apr 2014
Interview Descriptions: I applied on April 6th and got an on the spot phone interview (no prior notice) on April 25th. An interview was scheduled for April 30th during which I met the PI and a staff of coordinators. Everyone was very friendly and informative. I was being sold on the job more than I was being questioned about my abilities. Had to reach out to the PI two weeks after my interview to find out I was not offered the job.
Interview Questions: All questions were very straight forward. The most interesting one was, "If you could design your perfect study what would it be"

title: Grant Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: Long period between application submitted and phone call to set up an interview. Then a long period between interview and offer.
Interview Questions: The interview was conversational I didn't feel that there was a difficult or unexpected question.

title: Research Patient Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 months. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: HR takes a long time to get info to the right places. I have a PhD and wrote papers, but they still made me take an office skills and typing test. Once your info made it to the department hiring manager, I received a call for the interview. I applied in May and was hired in October. Received a call in Sept from the hiring manager, so HR sat on my application forever. They are known for this.
Interview Questions: All questions were expected. Handling confidentiality. Can I learn to take blood pressure. How would I handle having to reorganize what someone else poorly organized.

title: Clinical Research Coordinator II Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 months. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis in Mar 2014
Interview Descriptions:
I was notified via email by the School of Medicine Dept of Oncology that they wanted to interview me for an exciting opportunity but would not disclose the job.  I managed to figure out through the external applicant site that I was being considered for a job that I applied to nearly 4 months ago, (late Dec 2013).  

I was interviewed over the phone the following week with standard interview questions, several of which were unrelated which is to be expected.  The first question I was asked was why I wanted to work for WashU, and why I specifically wanted to work in a position where most people quit within six months of hire.  The interview ran for a good 30min and I was asked when I could start if I was offered a job on (undisclosed) date.  I was informed I'd be contacted in the next two weeks if they were interested in moving forward with me, which they weren't.

A note about WashU, I'm a recent MPH graduate, and for the past year have applied to 70 jobs with this company.  I networked at job fairs, was in direct contact with HR staff and was even offered help by the School of Medicine's chief of staff.  None of this helped at all, and the hiring manger I spoke to seemed surprised that I had applied to more than one position with the University.  (Note:  I asked her what job I was being considered, and the response was "Oh, you've applied to more than one job?")  I was also asked what salary I was looking for and stated I'm happy with the posted range.  The hiring manager then asked me to provide the salary range for the job claiming (said person) didn't know what it was.

I have no clue how you could ever get a job at WashU.  Maybe you need to be famous, maybe you need to be a relative of a current employee, or maybe you need to have all the luck in the world.
Interview Questions: Why do you want a job where most people quit within six months?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Mar 2014
Interview Descriptions: I was already working there and was transferring to another position. Very poor communication between old supervisor and new supervisor about starting, etc. Interview was casual but a little too casual. It would have been nice to get more info about the specifics of the job. Interview was done with the PI.
Interview Questions: What did you learn in your public health program?

title: Research Scientist Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Mar 2014
Interview Descriptions: The interview is pretty simple since I got my Ph.D., meet with several professors. answer several related questions. The most important thing is that your skills matched what they expected.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Mar 2014
Interview Descriptions: Applied online on website for position. Got a  call withing a week. First initial interview was on Skype.  After that they ask me to come on site for personal interview. I gave powerpoint presentation in front of 5 people. After that talk to my boss in person. I got the offer next day.
Interview Questions: What are you looking to do in postdoc? When can u join? Your strength and weakness? What are your short and long interview plans. Where do you see yourself in next 10 years?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview, long interviews with multiple managers.  Interviews lasted over an hour.  The hiring process included meeting with human resources, a urine test and a hair sample was taken for drug testing.  They cut out a significant chunk of hair and the employees who were involved in this process could not have possible been any ruder.  In addition to the interviews, references were checked, all that were listed.
Interview Questions: None, just the usual questions.

title: Librarian Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: Went relatively quickly for an academic library. I submitted an application and heard back in about a month that they wanted to schedule a phone interview. Phone interview with the search committee was about 30 minutes long and they asked technical and job-duties-related questions. I was invited for a campus visit shortly after. The visit was 1.5 days and included a series of group interviews, a presentation and open Q&A, and dinner and lunch. I got a job offer a week or so after they checked references. There was absolutely no room to negotiate salary or additional benefits. They do offer a good relocation package-- visit to find a place, pack and move, no storage or temporary housing though.
Interview Questions: There were no terribly difficult or unexpected questions. Most were related to job skills and trajectory of career. Some personality/working style questions.

title: Public Health Research Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Sept 2013
Interview Descriptions: Very simple interview - I emailed my resume and cover letter to the Project Coordinator and met with her for a 30-minute interview. She queried about my research experience and data analysis and software abilities. I heard back from her with an offer within a week.
Interview Questions: Have you had experience utilizing NVivo or qualitative analysis software? Have you conducted interviews?

title: Laser Lab Monitor Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis in Aug 2013
Interview Descriptions: You could send an email to the manager to express your interest about the job. And then you have to wait the manager to make a decision and receive another email to inform you are be selected.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions: Received a phone call from HR associate to review my resume -qualifications and skills; received a second phone call from HR associate to set up a face to face interview with potential supervisors; very easy to work with HR associate, very professional and helpful all way of my hiring process; I consider the Human Resources Department a very competent one.
Interview Questions: N/A

title: Postdoctoral Research Scholar Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jul 2013
Interview Descriptions: Applied online, followed by Skype interview and then an on-site. Upon completion of the on-site interview I was quickly offered the position, and accepted. The entire process went smoothly, but I didn't have to deal with HR that much, mainly the supervisor for whom I would be working.
Interview Questions: About my experience and ambitions

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: Filled out and application and got an email saying I was accepted
Interview Questions: No questions

title: Planner Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jun 2013
Interview Descriptions: Easy interview, very informal. The interview was direct and to the point. Met two professionals from the department for about 20 minutes. They were nice & cordial. We met in an office where they had copied of my resume. They asked a total of 5 questions and then the interview was over. HR emailed me 2 days later that they went with another candidate.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself.

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: I learned abou the opening through my friends who I went to a course in Woods Hole.  Coincidentally, there was a diversity recruiting event for the postdocs which i got.  First, night I spend dinner with the PI as ice breaker.  Then followed by full day of interview with lab members and seminar on my thesis project.  As soon as I got back home the PI called and sent me an offer letter for the position guaranteeing 5 yrs of my salary with his grant.
Interview Questions: Nothing in particular my PI and I hit it off immediately.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in May 2013
Interview Descriptions: I just emailed the principal investigator. Some of the senior students also work in that agency. So they are pretty familiar with our student cohort. Got an email expressing interest to talk in-person. Mainly discussed the current research projects to see if I am interested in working on them. After a week, I followed up and got the job.
Interview Questions: No difficult question.

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis
Interview Descriptions: Initial application online, then telephone interview, then first in person interview followed by panel interview.
Interview Questions: None, all questions were the standard interview questions.

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO)
Interview Descriptions: Met with all staff and management. Position fully explained. No surprises. Acted quickly to hire. Asked "How would you handle this situation" or "how would you solve this problem" type of questions.
Interview Questions: Would you have any difficulty firing someone?

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 3 months. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Feb 2013
Interview Descriptions: Only a phone interview.  No onsite visit was offered.  Considering the amount of grant money WUSTL labs typically have, would have been nice to have been offerered a chance to visit the lab in person.  Regretable not to visit the places.  Visiitng to see for oneself is highly important.  set up in lab was not as I expected, not very mature lab like i imagined.  Do no imagine..Please visit for yourself.
Interview Questions: Will you take the position if it is offered?

title: Instructor, College Or University Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 4 days. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: It was through my advisor, found it out, sent my resume, did it by person and it took about 10 minutes for the interview process to end. The staff was very friendly and helpful throughout the interview.
Interview Questions: How would you create the curriculum from scratch? What&amp;#039;s your ideal way of teaching?

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: The usual for an academic postdoc - site visit over a day and a half with the lab, gave one semi-private talk, and several meetings with faculty, current students, and current lab members.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in coming to St. Louis?

title: Graduate Student Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jan 2013
Interview Descriptions: Collegial, inviting and an all round great experience. They essentially introduce you to faculty from across the department and you get to appreciate the depth of opportunities that are available to you, if you choose to join. Other graduate students also participate in the recruitment process, so you do have the opportunity to ask questions and get an impression from them.
Interview Questions: Whether WashU in StL would be a location you could see yourself living in?

title: Lotus Notes Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied through a staffing agency. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Lake Saint Louis, MO) in Dec 2012
Interview Descriptions: It was a phone interview with IT managers that I would be reporting to on project.  It consisted of a review of my resume and past experiences working as a Lotus Notes Developer.  Working on a extended stay arrangement was discussed along with term and length of engagement.  The length of engagement was 3 months so interview was not as rigorous as one might have been for a longer stay.
Interview Questions: Have you ever worked for an educational institute?

title: Senior Prospect Research Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Oct 2012
Interview Descriptions: Submitted resume online in response opening posted on their website.

title: Senior Project Analyst - Finance Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions:
Some departments at Washington University use a behavorial assessment (Activity Vector Analysis-AVA) for assessing a candidate's behavioral fit to a position.  Based on your word selections to a couple of questions and a short description of yourself, the tool creates a candidate profile.  The profile consists of descriptions of natural behavior, natural tendencies, operating styles, and ideal environment.

About four days after applying online, I received an email from the hiring department that my application had been received along with instructions for completing the AVA.  After I completed and submitted the AVA, I received an email the next day with interview times.

The interview was a one-on-one situational interview with the hiring manager.  Many questions such as:
* Tell me a situation in which you had to make a difficult business decision
* How do you deal with changing priorities?
* Do you prefer to handle one task or many?

I would suggest the best way to prepare for a situational/behavioral interview is to research interview questions and spend a couple of days writing out your responses.  In doing this exercise, it will also ensure that you will have good examples of your work experiences to talk about during the interview that relate to the questions being asked.
Interview Questions: How do you deal with changing priorities, delays, or crisis?

title: Software Architect Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Sept 2010
Interview Descriptions: A friend posted the job on a developer group message board.  I fit the skills, so I applied.  Within 12 hours, the scientist who ran the lab contacted me to schedule an interview.  Within 1 week, I interviewed on site.  The scientist asked about my experience, but didn't have many technical questions.  The lab was just a cubical farm in a medical office building.  It didn't seem like a fun place to work.  Within 1 week, he contacted me with an offer, which was 25% too low.  He was limited by what the university would pay, but offered to create a special position with his startup to meet my salary requirements.  I was still interested and went to meet the team.  The team I would be guiding was collectively very intelligent and educated, but lacked engineering discipline. They claimed to have newly adopted agile methodologies and were very accepting of new technologies (clojure, scala, python). I scheduled a team pairing session for 1 week later. When pairing, I discovered they had not implemented any agile practices as they initially claimed. The team wrote no tests and had little communication.
Interview Questions: How would you improve quality of the product?

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: The process took 1 day. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Mar 2010
Interview Descriptions: I applied for and interviewed for several jobs at Wash U and overall they suck at getting back to you. People rarely give contact information and if you ask for a way to get in touch with them they refuse. If you are lucky enough to get the info for a follow up, they sometimes just don't answer you back. I have gone on interviews with them where the interviewer has been down right mean, talking about how apparently incompetent I am. What I don't understand is if they don't think I'm a good fit why even call me for an interview? I think they have a quota of people they have to interview before they can hire someone.

Interview Questions: N/A

title: Career Services Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Oct 2009
Interview Descriptions: I first was contacted about a phone interview and requested to take a few online assessments. One consisted of a personality test that let you choose words others would describe you as and what you truly would describe yourself as. The phone interview lasted about 30 to 45 minutes. The woman was from the Human Resources office at the university. She was very nice and she asked several interview questions. She might ask you to give examples of your work in certain situations and then would put you in a situation and ask you how you would react in that situation. After the phone interview, she had me schedule a computer test. They tested my abilities on Microsoft Word, Excel, and a Keyboarding test. I didn't do near as well on Word as I did on Excel. I used Excel everyday though and Word I haven't been familiar with since college. I do remember on the Word test you would have to draw graphs and add or subtract lines. Even before I took the skills test, the Career Services department head sent me an email and requested I interview with her. It was a very basic email, no emotion. I scheduled the interview two days after my skills test so I could better prepare. I was told my interview would be an hour and a half long in the career services center and that it would consist of 3 1:1 interviews. I interviewed with 3 women the day I arrived. They were all very friendly and I felt a wonderful rapport with them. They seemed very smart but still had a laid back attitude. They made me feel very comfortable and I am usually a nervous person. They asked your typical interview questions but wanted more detail in your answers. They asked for a lot of examples and how this job might benefit from your past experiences. My interview ended exactly when they said it would. I felt like it went extremely well but I sadly wasn't offered the job. The university is very popular and they constantly have applicants. I wouldn't be surprised if over 100 people applied for the position. It wasn't the easiest interview I ever had but it wasn't extremely difficult either. Altogether though, the interview process would be rated average to difficult. I wish the best of luck to all who apply. Just research the position and throw some facts in their direction. They don't ask too many questions about the University so I would just focus on learning as much about the department as you can and think of good examples from your past experiences that could apply to the available job. Good Luck!
Interview Questions: Each person would ask different questions for the most part. Just be prepared to give examples and make sure you have many.

title: Career Development Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at Washington University in St. Louis (Saint Louis, MO) in Jan 2008

I also sent my credentials via the online application process via the HR offices.   I was interviewed in 16 different meetings during eight onsite invitations.  Because I live in STL the process was perhaps more protracted than if I lived out-of-town.  They took a lot more care than the Fortune 100 companies I interviewed with and was hired within for much higher paying jobs with management responsibilities.
Interview Questions: There really were no difficult nor unexpected questions.  The style of interview was primarilly behavioral and I had much more experience than was needed to provide comprehensive answers based on empirical examples.
